title: Build Comments Feature from Scratch
description: The capstone lesson - design and implement a complete Comment system following MVC patterns
objectives: Design a new database table schema
Create a complete Model with CRUD and validation
Add a comments section to the task detail View
Handle relationships between Comments, Tasks, and Users

steps.title: Feature Overview
steps.content:
Welcome to the capstone lesson!

You'll build a COMPLETE feature from scratch: Comments on Tasks.

When complete, users can:
- Add comments to any task
- See all comments on a task detail page
- See who wrote each comment and when
- Delete their own comments

This involves ALL MVC layers:
- MODEL: Comment class with CRUD methods
- CONTROLLER: CommentController with routes
- VIEW: Comments section in task detail page
- DATABASE: New comments table

This lesson has 5 parts:
- Part A: Design the Comment model (database schema)
- Part B: Implement Comment CRUD methods
- Part C: Create CommentController routes
- Part D: Add comments section to task view
- Part E: Handle relationships (comment.user, task.comments)

Each part has a checkpoint. Take your time!

Let's start by designing the data model.
steps.hint: This is a real-world feature build - each part builds on the previous

steps.title: Part A: Design Comment Schema
steps.content:
First, design the database table for comments.

A Comment needs:
- id: unique identifier (integer, primary key)
- task_id: which task this comment belongs to (foreign key)
- user_id: who wrote the comment (foreign key)
- content: the comment text (string, required)
- created_at: when it was written (timestamp)

Relationships:
- Each comment belongs to ONE task (many-to-one)
- Each comment belongs to ONE user (many-to-one)
- Each task can have MANY comments (one-to-many)
- Each user can write MANY comments (one-to-many)

Create the migration file to add this table.
steps.hint: Look at the existing schema in backend/database/schema.sql for reference

steps.title: Part B: Create Comment Model
steps.content:
Now create the Comment Model class.

Create a new file: backend/models/comment.py

The Comment class needs:
1. validate() - check content is not empty, task_id and user_id exist
2. create() - insert new comment, return the created comment
3. get_by_id() - get a single comment with user info
4. get_by_task_id() - get all comments for a task with user info
5. delete() - remove a comment

Follow the patterns you've seen in User.py and Task.py:
- Use @staticmethod for methods
- Use @log_method_call decorator
- Include docstrings explaining MVC flow
- Handle foreign key validation
steps.hint: Look at Task.py for patterns on handling relationships

checkpoint.instructions: Create the Comment.create() method that validates input, inserts a new comment, and returns the created comment with user info.
checkpoint.codeTemplate:
"""
Comment Model - Handles comment data and relationships.

MVC Role: MODEL
- Manages comment data structure
- Handles validation (content not empty, valid task/user IDs)
- Executes database queries for CRUD operations
- Returns structured data to Controllers

Relationships:
- Each comment belongs to one Task (task_id foreign key)
- Each comment belongs to one User (user_id foreign key)
- Comments are loaded with user info to avoid N+1 queries

Covered in: Lesson 8 (building a complete feature)
"""

import re
from backend.database.connection import execute_query
from backend.utils.decorators import log_method_call


class Comment:
    """
    Comment Model representing task comments with user authorship.
    
    Database table: comments
    Relationships: belongs_to Task, belongs_to User
    """
    
    @staticmethod
    @log_method_call
    def validate(content: str, task_id: int, user_id: int) -> None:
        """
        Validate comment data before saving.
        
        Args:
            content: The comment text
            task_id: ID of the task this comment belongs to
            user_id: ID of the user writing the comment
        
        Raises:
            ValueError: If validation fails
        """
        # Check content is not empty
        if not content or not content.strip():
            raise ValueError("Comment content cannot be empty")
        
        # Check task exists
        task_query = "SELECT id FROM tasks WHERE id = ?"
        task = execute_query(task_query, (task_id,), fetch_one=True)
        if not task:
            raise ValueError(f"Task with ID {task_id} does not exist")
        
        # Check user exists
        user_query = "SELECT id FROM users WHERE id = ?"
        user = execute_query(user_query, (user_id,), fetch_one=True)
        if not user:
            raise ValueError(f"User with ID {user_id} does not exist")
    
    @staticmethod
    @log_method_call
    def create(content: str, task_id: int, user_id: int) -> dict:
        """
        Create a new comment.
        
        MVC Flow:
        1. Controller receives POST with comment data
        2. Controller calls Comment.create()
        3. This method validates data
        4. Inserts into database
        5. Returns created comment with user info
        
        Args:
            content: The comment text
            task_id: ID of the task to comment on
            user_id: ID of the user writing the comment
        
        Returns:
            dict: The created comment with nested user object
        
        Raises:
            ValueError: If validation fails
        """
        # Validate input
        Comment.validate(content, task_id, user_id)
        
        # ADD YOUR CODE HERE:
        # 1. Insert the comment into the database
        # 2. Get the new comment's ID
        # 3. Fetch and return the complete comment with user info

Must use execute_query() to run database queries
Must return the created comment

steps.title: Part B (continued): get_by_task_id Method
steps.content:
Now add the method to get all comments for a task.

This method will:
1. Accept a task_id parameter
2. Query all comments for that task
3. Include user information for each comment (JOIN)
4. Order by created_at (newest or oldest first)
5. Return a list of comment dictionaries

This is similar to Task.get_all() but filtered by task_id.
steps.hint: Use LEFT JOIN to include user info with each comment

checkpoint.instructions: Add a method to get all comments for a specific task, including the author's user information.
checkpoint.codeTemplate:

@log_method_call

    Get all comments for a specific task with user info.
    
    MVC Flow:
    1. Controller loads task detail page
    2. Controller calls Comment.get_by_task_id(task_id)
    3. This method queries comments + user info in one query
    4. Returns list of comments to Controller
    5. Controller passes to View for rendering
    
    Args:
        task_id: The task's ID
    
    Returns:
        list: Comments with nested user objects, ordered by created_at
    
    Performance Note:
    - Uses JOIN to include user info (avoids N+1 problem)
    - For 50 comments: 1 query instead of 51 queries!
    """
    # ADD YOUR CODE HERE:
    # 1. Write a SELECT query joining comments with users
    # 2. Filter by task_id
    # 3. Order by created_at (DESC for newest first, or ASC for oldest)
    # 4. Transform results to include nested user object

    query = """
        SELECT 
            comments.*,
            users.id as user_id,
            users.name as user_name,
            users.email as user_email
        FROM comments
        INNER JOIN users ON comments.user_id = users.id
        WHERE comments.task_id = ?
        ORDER BY comments.created_at ASC

steps.title: Part C: Create CommentController
steps.content:
Now create the Controller to handle comment routes.

Create a new file: backend/controllers/comment_controller.py

Routes needed:
1. POST /tasks/<task_id>/comments - Create a comment on a task
2. POST /tasks/<task_id>/comments/<comment_id>/delete - Delete a comment

Note: We're nesting comment routes under tasks because comments always belong to a task.

The Controller should:
- Parse form data
- Call Comment Model methods
- Handle errors gracefully
- Redirect back to task detail page
steps.hint: Nest comment routes under /tasks/<task_id>/comments for RESTful design

checkpoint.instructions: Create a new controller file with a Blueprint and a route to create comments.
checkpoint.codeTemplate:
"""
Comment Controller - Handles comment-related HTTP requests.

MVC Role: CONTROLLER
- Receives HTTP requests for comment operations
- Calls Comment Model methods
- Handles errors and redirects
- Returns responses to client

URL Prefix: Nested under tasks (/tasks/<task_id>/comments)

Routes:
    POST /tasks/<task_id>/comments          - Create comment
    POST /tasks/<task_id>/comments/<id>/delete - Delete comment

Covered in: Lesson 8 (building a complete feature)
"""

from flask import Blueprint, request, redirect, url_for, flash
from backend.models.comment import Comment
from backend.utils.decorators import log_method_call

# Create Blueprint for comment routes
# Nested under tasks for RESTful URLs
comments_bp = Blueprint('comments', __name__)


@comments_bp.route('/tasks/<int:task_id>/comments', methods=['POST'])
@log_method_call
def create(task_id):
    """
    Create a new comment on a task.
    
    MVC Flow:
    1. Controller receives POST /tasks/<id>/comments
    2. Controller extracts content and user_id from form
    3. Controller calls Comment.create(content, task_id, user_id)
    4. Model validates and inserts
    5. Controller redirects back to task detail with message
    
    HTTP: POST /tasks/<task_id>/comments
    Form data: content, user_id
    
    Note: In a real app, user_id would come from session/auth.
    For learning, we pass it in the form.
    """
    # Get form data
    content = request.form.get('content', '').strip()
    user_id = request.form.get('user_id', '').strip()
    
    # ADD YOUR CODE HERE:
    # 1. Convert user_id to integer
    # 2. Try to create the comment
    # 3. Handle ValueError (validation errors)
    # 4. Flash success or error message
    # 5. Redirect to task detail page
    
    return redirect(url_for('tasks.show', task_id=task_id))

- TaskController.show()

  - Comment.get_by_task_id()
- Template rendered with task + comments

**Database Inspector:**
- SELECT for task (with JOINs)
- SELECT for comments (with JOINs)

**State Inspector:**

- comments array with nested user objects

steps.title: Capstone Complete!
steps.content:
Congratulations! You've built a complete MVC feature from scratch!

What you accomplished:
1. Designed a new database schema (comments table)
2. Created a new Model (Comment) with CRUD operations
3. Built a new Controller (CommentController) with routes
4. Updated an existing View to display and create comments
5. Handled relationships between three entities (Comments, Tasks, Users)
6. Used JOINs to avoid N+1 query problems
7. Implemented proper validation and error handling

You followed MVC separation:
- Model: All database logic in Comment class
- View: HTML templates display data, forms collect input
- Controller: Routes parse requests, call models, render views

This is exactly how you build features in production MVC applications!

Next steps:
- Try adding a delete comment feature
- Add edit functionality for comments
- Add user authentication to track who's commenting

You now understand MVC architecture in practice!
steps.hint: You've mastered the MVC pattern - apply these concepts to any feature!

options: Comments belong to Tasks and Users (many-to-one), Tasks and Users have many Comments (one-to-many)
Comments, Tasks, and Users all have many-to-many relationships
Comments belong to Tasks only, Users are unrelated

checkpoint.correct: Comments belong to Tasks and Users (many-to-one), Tasks and Users have many Comments (one-to-many)
